awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Tuning Extreme-scale Storage Stack through Deep Reinforcement Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Many research domains, such as high-energy physics, climate science, astrophysics, combustion science, and computational biology, need to process large amounts of data. Such domains are heavily relying on the capabilities of high performance computing (HPC) systems to manage and efficiently process massive amounts of data. Consequently, applications in the aforementioned research domains require highly optimized performance on the HPC storage systems that store, manage, and manipulate data. This project aims to utilize deep reinforcement learning methods to fine-tune the HPC storage system for optimized performance.

This research explores the feasibility of leveraging deep reinforcement learning to optimize HPC storage systems by: (a) Creating a deep learning based HPC storage stack model; (b) Remodeling existing HPC storage stack to support automated configuration and tuning; (c) Collecting training datasets and training the storage stack model; and (d) utilizing the model as a responsive and playable virtual environment to learn the best policy to tune parameters. 

As a collaborative project, this research aims to advance the domain knowledge of both HPC storage systems and machine learning. The enhanced performance on the HPC storage stack will in turn benefit scientific discovery and thus our society. The investigators will integrate research, education, and outreach efforts during the course of this project, including recruiting and retaining of underrepresented students, mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, integrating research findings into curriculum, and publishing and disseminating results.

The data collected to train the storage stack model will be shared at https://discl.cs.ttu.edu/tuningstorage while the code of machine learning at https://github.com/forrestbao/DL4SC. Results and data will be made available by the time of publication. The data will be annotated as appropriate to facilitate interpretation. The principal investigators will strive to maintain the repositories as long as possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported Texas Tech University, a public state university and a Hispanic Serving Institution in west Texas, to conduct forward-looking research to study the feasibility of leveraging machine learning methods to optimize storage stack, a critical component of high performance computing (HPC) systems. The research findings help build new methods to improve the efficiency of HPC systems, which has direct impacts on many science and engineering disciplines that rely on HPC systems to conduct computer simulations for scientific discovery. Additionally, many undergraduate and graduate students were trained throughout this project either directly via participating in this project or indirectly through courses and activities offered. This project contributed to both new knowledge discovery and the workforce development for the nation and our society.

Intellectual Merit: The heterogeneity and complexity of modern high-performance computing (HPC) storage systems make tuning and optimizing them extremely challenging. Existing methods fall short in handling multiple storage layers adaptively. Throughout this project, first, we extensively studied the deep and heterogeneous storage hierarchies in large-scale HPC systems and identified key resource management and job scheduling strategies using machine learning and reinforcement learning methods. Second, we developed machine learning-based data analysis tools to identify storage stack bottlenecks based on application traces and logs. Through our research, we observed various limitations in current HPC systems and developed new methods and algorithms to address those limitations. We built prototypes to validate and study the efficacy of those methods and algorithms too. Third, we extensively studied the energy consumption of HPC systems including storage systems and demonstrated the effectiveness of machine learning methods in optimizing both the performance and energy consumption. These research findings provided insights about HPC storage systems and offered new solutions to build more efficient and powerful HPC machines. The research results have been disseminated via 20 publications, three doctoral dissertations, and two Master thesis. Many publications have appeared in top-tier venues in the field, such as IEEE Transactions on Computers, ACM Transactions on Storage, ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference, International Conference on Parallel Processing, etc. These publications disseminated the research findings developed throughout this project to the broad community.

Broader Impacts: Through this project, we conducted in-depth research to better understand HPC storage systems and identify key performance bottlenecks. We explored how storage and computation can be managed and scheduled using deep learning and reinforcement learning approaches. Our findings highlight a viable path toward achieving the automated management of HPC storage systems. Additionally, we investigated the energy consumption of HPC storage systems and studied the potential of machine learning approaches to enhance energy efficiency. The results of this research will contribute to the development of more efficient and powerful HPC systems. As high performance computing continues to be a crucial tool for scientific discovery, this research enhances the productivity of scientific computing and has far-reaching impacts. Throughout the project, students received extensive training and professional development. More specifically, three doctoral students graduated with the support of this project, and approximately twenty-five undergraduate students gained valuable experience through student cluster competition activities. Additionally, four Master students were also trained throughout this project. This research project has helped cultivate a globally competitive workforce and benefits both the nation and society.
